story:
We are the Aspire Higher Race team from Oxford Hills Middle School located in South Paris Maine. We are a group of 35 students, engaging in a hands on experiential learning program. At Oxford Hills Middle School, there are many different “Quests” you can do. This one just happened to be building and managing a race car from the ground up! We are the first Middle School in the country, and possibly even the whole world, doing this! This truly is a one of a kind experience for us. This experience really is important to us, because it gets us out from behind a desk. It gets us involved with our community and teaches us real word problem solving. By sitting behind a desk we don’t always learn the things we need to get us ready for the real world as adults. Through this program we are in the process of changing what it means to come to school!

Oxford Hills Middle School has three trimester experiences: Humanities, STEM, and the Arts. Each experience is focused around different things. STEM is focused around Science Technology Engineering and Math, Humanities this year is focusing on War and Conflict, and the Arts teaches visual and performing arts. Every Thursday our school has "Quest Day" where students participate in different activities depending on which team they are on. Here are some examples:

The Arts:

~Costume Designing

~Graphic Novel

~Culinary 

Humanities:

~Weapons of Warfare

~The Holocaust, Genocide and Human Rights

~Meeting Living Heroes to Preserve their Stories

STEM:

 Eighth Grade:

~Making/Designing and Engineering mouse trap cars

~Engineering "roller coasters"

Seventh Grade:

~Planning a trip to "Mars"


As you can see, at Oxford Hills Middle School we are getting kids out from behind desks and creating hands-on learning for them! With these changes to our school, attendance rates have gone up and kids are more motivated to learn! The race car team isn't the only hands on learning going on at Oxford Hills Middle School!

   We are looking to raise around $15,000 to help us with our program.  This money will go to the race car itself, which a team of seventh and eighth graders are in the process of building right now! Some money will also go toward the start-up cost of merchandise, which our graphic design team has been designing for us to sell! As you may know, before we can buy these things for the car and buy the merchandise we need some money so we can afford it and keep our program alive for future generations!  If we don’t reach our entire goal, we will still put it to good use. It will be dispersed through the building and engineering aspect of our program, and it will also be used to buy merchandise so we can sell at different races we will be racing in!
   Our program is one of a kind! This program gets us ready for the real world when we get out of High School and College. This program helps us learn different aspects that adults need. For some of us, we know what we might want to go on to college for and make a living off of! Some want to be mechanics, secretaries, reporters, and those are just a few examples! There are many students working hard with this project, so far we have been on our local channels 8 (ABC) and 6 (NBC).  We were also mentioned on Nickelodeon News. We were also mentioned on Speed51, and our driver Spencer Morse has been interviewed multiple times, even on TV! Our program is teaching us real world situations.  On behalf of all 35 students, we would like you to know that this program has taught us more then we may ever learn in a classroom! We have learned speaking skills and mechanical skills, financial skills, and many other skills that we will need when we get out of college or high school!
   The purpose of this fundraising campaign is to help us keep this program alive for years to come. Without your help, we may not be able to do this program in future generations! As of right now we are trying to expand this program into the high school so some of us can continue participating in this program! All of the students take great pride in this group, and we want to see it succeed.  we can’t do that without your help! We have already gotten sponsors but that's not all that we need! We need help from other generous people such as yourself! If someone you knew had this opportunity and they were in this program, wouldn’t you help them out? So what do you say? Any donation will help us out a lot! Anything you can spare will be greatly appreciated!
Please spread the word and help us reach our goal! Use the Indiegogo share tools to get the word out! Our group would love to achieve our goal, and you could help make that possible! Please follow us on twitter, Facebook and check out our website!

story:
The value of strong communication abilities is limitless. Individuals' interpersonal and verbal skills either propel or prevent personal and professional success. At Professor Peaches, we believe that sound communication abilities build the foundation for children to achieve their dreams. The diagram below highlights the significant role that communication plays for all individuals throughout life


Who We Are:

Professor Peaches is a proprietary tutoring program employing a range of techniques and modalities, tailored to help children build and hone their verbal and nonverbal (i.e., body language, eye contact, listening) abilities. The program is designed with a holistic approach to speaking ability. The content has been carefully created to build and develop a comprehensive array of communication-based skills. The Professor Peaches “Power Wheel” illustrates the curriculum components, which together work to form the heart of the program:

                                

 At Professor Peaches, we believe the most efficient and effective way to strengthen and refine communication abilities is through practice. Therefore, the structure of each tutoring session is heavily based in experiential learning. Weekly homework assignments are designed to reinforce and help ingrain the specific skills focused on in class.   


Professor Peaches & Faculty:

The materials have been designed to be fun and engaging in nature. All the key communication areas and themes have been allocated to a professor who is a subject matter expert and is featured throughout the program and in homework assignments. The faculty serve to create a playful structure. All classes are taught by real staff who are highly qualified and trained and are carefully selected to ensure a perfect fit for children at Professor Peaches.


Homework is completed with the assistance of set templates. Two examples of homework assignments are provided below:


Why This Needs to Exist:

Society expects people to be confident and engaging speakers despite the fact many individuals never receive any training in this area. The lack of education focused on communication skills presents a tremendous number of problems; from people unable to express themselves to people actually being afraid to speak. Comedian Jerry Seinfield perfectly highlights this dilemma in a joking yet meaningful manner, "According to most studies, people's number one fear is public speaking. Number two is death. Death is number two. Does that sound right? This means to the average person, if you go to a funeral, you're better off in the casket than doing the eulogy." This needs to be changed. Communication skills are vital. The ability to communicate well should not be viewed as the frosting on the cake. It should be viewed as the cake itself! And at the end of the day, well, who doesn’t like cake?  Below are some additional quotes that illustrate the power and importance of communication:


Our expansion plan:

The Professor Peaches curriculum has been optimized and refined after undergoing beta testing and is now ready to begin making an impact! The next steps are to open the very first location and implement our detailed expansion plan to facilitate the presence of Professor Peaches globally. There are approximately 2 billion children in the world. Our dream is to help reach these children so that they are given the skills to communicate well. To express themselves. To believe in themselves. To have confidence in themselves. To make the world theirs!

Please visit our website at www.professorpeaches.com to have a closer look at us.


What We Need:

Our goal for 2015 is to open the inaugural Professor Peaches Center; we have selected Chicago for the launch city, and specifically the Skokie/Evanston area. In order to open the doors of the first Professor Peaches Center we need your help to make the components of opening a center come together such as:    

  • Securing a lease for the first Professor Peaches Center
  • Configuring the Center into a stimulating and engaging learning space
  • Printing and publication of program materials
  • Purchasing children's enrollment package supplies
  • Marketing and promotion of Professor Peaches

In addition, we are excited to announce that part of your donation will go toward securing cost-free tuition for children who qualify. Thank you in advance for your generosity. Every dollar raised by this campaign will go towards the aforementioned necessities.


Professor Peaches Co-Founders:                   

                                 

Kimberly graduates with her Ph.D. in clinical psychology from Yeshiva University in August 2015. She previously received her M.A. in clinical psychology from Teachers College, Columbia University and B.A. in clinical psychology from Tufts University. Stefan is a registered Chartered Accountant with the Institute of Chartered Accounts Australia and has a double major in finance and accounting from the University of New South Wales.

We have capitalized on both Kimberly’s clinical psychology experience, with extensive practical experience in designing and developing educational training materials, and Stefan’s professional experience plus his experience with tutoring and volunteering within elementary schools. Additionally, we expanded our combined skills by each obtaining public speaking certifications. As co-founders of Professor Peaches, we are both passionate about helping children build their best possible foundation for life. 


Team:

The course curriculum has had contributions from a fantastic team of people. Our team consists of a talented group who specialize in the fields of education, psychology, and program development.



Other Ways You Can Help:

Please feel free to share our campaign information with others!!


The Perks!

Please see the sidebar of this campaign website for a list of the perks based on the donation amount.  Below is the visual presentation of the perks for your viewing pleasure! 

CAMPAIGN UPDATE - Our new perk gives you the power to vote for where you would like the future Professor Peaches city locations to open. Your city. Your country. It is your vote! After your dollar donation we will promptly email you to ask for your selection. Individuals that donate more than $1 are also eligible to take advantage of this perk and will similarly be emailed after their donation.


CAMPAIGN UPDATE - we are excited to release a new category of perks! Your contributions can now be used to enroll your child in the Professor Peaches program. Indiegogo backers will receive priority enrollment and will not need to pay, having already secured their spot through their discounted contribution. 

Please note that you must be able to attend classes in person, which will be located in Skokie/Evanston of the Chicago area.

story:
Who is FootPrints International (FPI)?

+ FPI is comprised of students and community leaders dedicated to operationalizing this mission by facilitating the creation of satellite organizations in colleges and communities around the world, to share its vision and promote its objectives.

+ The core principle of FPI is that we all share a common destiny no matter where we come from. FPI is committed to building relationships between peoples globally by linking local chapters with international partners. This will inspire and enable understanding between communities around the world, and promote harmony and cooperation between future generations.

Why FootPrints International?

+ The vision of Footprints International (FPI) is to enhance the well being of underprivileged youth around the world, by providing resources (shoes, educational materials, and mentors) that can enable them to pursue learning that is essential in helping them uplift themselves, and the quality of life for their families and communities.

+ In many countries around the world, foot diseases prevent students from attending school; we hope to help solve this problem.

Recent and Future Projects

March 2014 500 pairs of gently used shoes were washed and delivered to two hundred students in a middle school, Government Technical School Zang-Tabi village (Cameroon). click here to see more

December 2014 FootPrints International sent 250 pairs of shoes to an orphanage in Accra, Ghana.

March 2015 300 pairs shoes, 20 boxes of donated educational resources from Acaletics Inc., and personal letters addressed to 1,000 school children will be shipped and delivered in Johannesburg, South Africa. click here to see more

July 2015 FootPrints International will ship shoes and educational supplies to 1,000 school children in Cameroon in summer 2015.

September 2015 FootPrints International hopes to build on its success at Cornell University (the first chapter), by creating two new community chapters during fall 2015. We will strive to enhance cooperation between chapters.

Your contributed funds will be used to provide the items listed below to 500 students at Masizani Primary School, Rethabiseng Primary School, Knobongwane Primary School, and Diepkloof Daycare Center in Johannesburg, South Africa:

-Mathematics textbooks for grades 5-12 donated by Acaletics Inc. 

- Over 200 flashcard decks for addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division donated by Acaletics Inc.

- Language arts workbooks

- Dictionaries/Thesaurus

- Pencils, pens, erasers, glue sticks

- Personalized letters addressed to each student written by college athletes

- A pair of recycled/refurbished athletic walking shoes to attend school.

Other Ways You Can Help

There is incredible power in sharing. The FPI team would be honored if you shared this project with your family, friends, coworkers, classmates, and that person next to you at the bus stop.

Indiegogo provides awesome sharing tools--please use these!

If you are interested in learning more about FootPrints International, please click here.

Thanks friends, let's do this!!!!!

Note: Contributed funds will be used to ship educational material and shoes to students in South Africa. Extra funds will be used to create additional FootPrints chapters and help support donations to youth in developing countries where we have established partnerships.

story:
Rotary Club of Maechan is seeking additional funding for rural students hoping to go the University.  Last year we assisted 50 students with starter scholarships plus five more in need of travelling money to reach schools where they had already received scholarships.  We would like to be able to help that many more again this year but need your help.

Starter scholarships allow students to enter a University and become familiar with a new way of life without having to worry about finding jobs immediately.  It provides the boost upwards towards eventually attaining degrees and discovering their full potential.

The initial cost of attending the state University is about $350 to $400 and covers registration, uniforms, books and the dorm. While that may not sound like much, it is a daunting sum to a family often earning half that much or less per month.  Students may, and often do, take out government loans if they hold Thai nationality papers. 

Unfortunately, over 300,000 people who were born into Thailand Hill tribes were not registered at birth with the government and hold no papers.  Essentially they are non-persons, ineligible for loans, certain jobs and even drivers’ licenses.  They must work to support themselves while attending school.  I am happy to report that, even with that handicap, many of these kids are attaining educations and are joining the mainstream of the society and making valuable contributions in all walks of life.

Some who never imagined a life beyond the corn or cabbage fields or rice paddies, are discovering that they can have choices for their futures and are anxious to embrace them.  One such recipient is in her second year and the top student in her major, a floor manager in her dorm and the President of the University Rotaract Club.  Another is studying law while others have become teachers, nurses, business men and even doctors.

These young people are the future of Thailand and deserving of assistance.  If you give up a visit to your local coffee shop one day a week, you can make a difference in the life of one of these young people.  Think about it; a coffee you really don’t need, or the education of a young person desiring an education and a  better life.

All of our scholarship recipients must have goals and plans for attaining them.  They must show themselves to be worthy of assistance.  We give special attention to orphans or young people from single parent families or families where disability or disease is a factor.  Again those without Thai nationality papers have limited access to other funding and that is a consideration.

Imagine, if you will, coming from a family earning less than $100 a month that must support not only itself, but perhaps grandparents as well.  Imagine the hopelessness the parents feel when they see their child want to go to school, but are unable to help.  Now, imagine that joy when an avenue opens and their child is provided an opportunity to attend the university, train for and obtain a job and improve his or her life and that of the family as well.  You can help to bring that joy to a family with your contribution today.  

We have received the applications and interviewed over 80 young people asking for assistance this year.  Many come from heartrending circumstances and will not be able to continue their educations without support from all of us.  As Rotary believes, join us today and make the world a better place.

and obtain a job and improve his or her life and that of the family as well.  You can help to bring that joy to a family
with your contribution today.  We have received the applications and
interviewed over 80 young people asking for assistance this year.  Many come from heartrending circumstances
and will not be able to continue their educations without support from all of
us.  As Rotary believes, join us today and make the world a
better place.

story:
Who are we?


We (Darbee and Grisel) are Masters candidates in the religious studies department at Florida International University in Miami which is where we met and first began talking about the religion and politics of Myanmar-Burma. We were both very interested in Buddhism, feminism, and religious violence; Burma was an obvious choice for the research that is the basis for each of our thesis projects. This summer, if we secure the funds, we will be boarding a plane to Southeast Asia to conduct fieldwork and research on the thila-shins (Burmese Buddhist nuns) who reside in Myanmar-Burma!

In Burma, Buddhist nuns do not reap the benefits that come with full ordination (like the monks do) because they are not allowed to be fully ordained. Nuns in Burma are referred to as "thila-shins," meaning "one who practices the teachings dharma," and it is as far as they can climb in the spiritual ladder of Buddhism. This alone is noteworthy, but what is even more curious, is the fully ordained status of the nationalist monks who are part of the 969 movement. Their leader, who Time magazine called "the Buddhist Bin Laden," uses Buddhist teachings and the exploitation of Burmese women to justify the sometimes violent actions of their organization.

In order to complete our Masters Thesis and thus graduate, we need to travel to Myanmar-Burma to engage with these women who seldom have a voice outside the confinement of their own country. By donating to our campaign, you not only get to help us graduate, you get to be a part of promoting gender equality across the globe and give women who rarely receive recognition a voice! Help us shed light and awareness on women in Burmese society! 


What We Need & What You Get

Darbee and Grisel want to raise around $3,385 big ones! That sounds like a lot, but here's the breakdown:

1. Flights alone to Southeast Asia are expensive, Both roundtrip flights cost $1,600.00

2. Hotels in Myanmar-Burma aren't super expensive, but they're not free! Here's a link to the hostel we'll be staying in that's about 15 to 20 dollars a night: http://www.tripadvisor.com/Hotel_Review-g739122-d3847666-Reviews-Shwe_Pyae_Sone_Guest_House-Sagaing_Sagaing_Region.html We'll be staying around 45 days and this comes to about $675.00

3. We figure we'll each need about 500 dollars for food

4. And we've factored in another 500 for miscellaneous/emergencies/donations to the nunnery.

This puts us up to a grand total of $5,875.00! We've each already raised $1,200.00 which puts us up to $2,400.00. We're hoping to raise the remaining $3,385.00 before we leave in June. If we don't reach our entire goal, we will have to get creative, but both of us intend to use whatever we raise towards our trip. If we raise over our goal then it will go to the nuns of the Sakyadhita Thilashin nunnery school in Sagaing, Myanmar-Burma.

The Impact


Myanmar-Burma is labeled by some as "the last frontier," for how secluded it can be from the outside world. It's elusiveness is something we are hoping to capture in our fieldwork. By contributing to our campaign, you are contributing to something deeper than just our education, you are supporting the idea that we should all be globally aware. It's hard to see outside of ourselves sometimes, to imagine a life different than our own, or to see that things could be worse. By exposing the lives people lead in a completely different environment than what we're used to, we hope to promote the idea that there is a common thread of humanity that connects us all.


Risks & Challenges

 For a long time, the political climate in Myanmar has made its people reluctant to answer questions about the government, and the monastic community is no exception. Monks and nuns are discouraged from getting involved in political affairs (affairs like full ordination for women and the perspective on the 969). However, we have been preparing for this for months, and are more than prepared to use our expertise in the field of ethnography to gain the trust of our informants and respondents. Because we plan on being there well over a month, we hope to build lasting and trusting relationships with the nuns in order to fully unearth what it means to be a Buddhist woman in Myanmar-Burma.

On top of the difficulty of extracting delicate information, the pressure of having to gather usable data for the most important document we will have to write in our academic career thus far, and being away from those we love in a strange place; we also run the risk of going for extended amounts of time without many western luxuries we are used to! Regular internet connection, access to plumbing and showers, and comfortable beds may be foreign to us during our time in Southeast Asia. These risks are small compared to what we believe we can accomplish if we complete this research. These calculated risks seem small compared to the idea that we get to help the women of Myanmar-Burma and promote gender equality and peace across the globe.

Other Ways You Can Help

Any little bit helps, even the smallest donation can help us reach our goal! But we understand financial situations and if you're not in one to donate, fear not! You can still contribute by sharing the link to others! :)
Please please, share the link!

story:
Gardeneers is a new and growing non-profit organization that implements weekly garden education programs in Chicago schools. We work primarily in schools located in low-income communities that are considered food deserts-- where there is a lack of convenient access to affordable, fresh, and healthy food. I

n these communities, children are significantly affected, as nutrition directly impacts a child’s mental and physical development. 




Our mission is to enable students to:

  • enrich their knowledge of nutrition

  • increase their access to nutrition

  • connect with their community

  • become stewards of the environment





Our vision is that all children will understand that access to healthy food is not a privilege- it is a right that all people deserve.  



What we do:

Gardeneers visits schools on a weekly basis to lead garden education programs. Students are active participants in the maintenance of their own school garden, from which they get to reap the harvest and numerous mental, physical and emotional benefits that go along with school gardening.  



Gardeneers is the only organization in Chicago dedicated to providing full-service school garden programs. Many schools lack the time and resources to sustain a garden, particularly during the summertime. The external support provided by Gardeneers sets up a school garden for success, without relying on teachers who are oftentimes overworked.



One of our major goals is to bring healthy produce back into the school cafeteria and the local community. As such, we are certified in the CPS “Eat What You Grow” Garden-to-Cafeteria program and adhere to all food safety guidelines and standards.  


In our first year we’ve worked with 9 schools, working with over 500 students on a weekly basis.
For our second year, we are doubling our program efforts, with a goal of 20 schools served in 2015.

But to do this, we need your SUPPORT! Gardeneers is seeking $15,000 to support our school garden programs. Your donations go towards our garden infrastructure, compost, soil, seedlings, garden tools, and the program staff that supports the success of school gardens, and the introduction to outdoor experiential education for students in the inner city.

Please open your hearts and your wallets for this cause. We are planting healthy futures for the children of Chicago!  


  • More than one third of children and adolescents in the U.S. are overweight or obese. (CDC 2012)

  • Studies show that children's knowledge of vegetables and willingness to taste them increases when they participate in garden based learning activities. (Langellotto and Gupta 2012)

  • Gardening and preparing food at school, combined with nutrition education, increases children’s  preference  for  fruit  and  vegetables. (FAO 2010)
  • The American Community Gardening Association attributes community and school gardens to an increase in home prices for residences near the garden, a reduction in violent and non-violent crime in the neighborhood, and an overall increase in the feeling of safety (2009). 

Other Ways You Can Help

Every dollar counts! Even the smallest donations make a huge impact. If you are unable to contribute, spread the word about Gardeneers through your networks. 



THANK YOU for your support!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Olympia Zampathas and I am a journalism major at San Francisco State University the Spring 2015 managing editor for Xpress Magazine.
Last semester, I served as copy editor on the publication and really fell in love with it. I didn't know I would ever like magazine form writing before being a part of the publication.

I like being able to tell a story more than give a brief summary or events and I think that is the importance of having a magazine on and representing a public university community.

But because we are a public university, sometimes we lack the funding for what we need to make our publication really shine.

We want more people to know about us and how we serve the campus community. We need more locations on campus with magazine stands and a product made of our materials we are proud of.

What We Need & What You Get

  • What we really need are magazine stands that are visible on multiple locations on San Francisco States campus to expand our reach and our product to be made out of higher quality materials so people will want to pick it up. It's a fantastic product - read through some of our stories online . We had some great writers and photographers last semester and we're incredibly enthusiastic to do even more this semester.
  • Every penny counts. The staff and I have big dreams, but relatively small wallets. Every donation will be recognized in our last print issue of this spring, due to come out in April, on our website, and across our social media platforms.

Goals

  • To put up two indoor and four outdoor stands: our stands right now are few and far between - and not very noticeable. Putting up new stands will help us as a publication stand out on campus. Right now, there are two dedicated magazine stands, while the rest of the copies are put on top of the campus newspaper on distribution day. We want our hard work and reporting to be seen. The models we have chosen are due to price and how useful we think these will be. The price of getting all six comes out to around $650 with tax before shipping.
  • To gain enough funds for glossy and color pages for the magazine: we hope to make getting glossy or color pages a sustainable aspect that this magazine will carry on past this semester, but we're just starting out getting advertisements this semester. Hopefully, by the time fall semester comes around, we will have enough advertisers to put out a glossy, colored magazine on our own. The extra $350 will be used to improve the materials are print copy is made from.

The Impact

You donating means a lot to us. The staff here at Xpress Magazine is putting out quality work and deserves to be seen and appreciated in the best light possible - we just can't afford to do so on our own. Thank you for all of your support and contribution.

Challenges

The only challenge I can foresee is not having enough funding. The staff this year is so driven and full of energy for this publication, even if we don't reach our goal, we will be making waves. Ask our editor-in-chief, Tami Benedict, yourself. You'll see, there's no doubt in her mind whether we're going to have a brilliant semester. This is just the kind of energy we need, and luckily, have to make an amazing product and make all of this possible..

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, we totally understand - we're all broke, college students trying to work in media after all. But there are other ways you can help:
  • Like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter, or Instagram
  • Subscribe to our website
  • Advertise with us! We do both print and online ads - email us at xpressmagsfsu@gmail.com for a quote (they're really very cheap). We also distribute magazines to multiple locations in and around the Bay Area.
  • Share our campaign! Please, we'd love if everyone shared this. Every dollar will get us closer to our goal.

story:
Kids Riding Bikes by Nine13 Sports NW

Nine13 Sports NW delivers educational programming promoting health, wellness and exercise to youth in the Northwest. Kids Riding Bikes is a youth program that promotes an active lifestyle through the sport of cycling. We integrate the traditional bicycle with technology to introduce cycling as a fun physical activity that has lifelong benefits for both the individual and community.


How it works...

Single-speed bikes are connected to a computer simulator. Electronic stands control resistance, making it easier or more difficult to pedal. For example, resistance increases when simulating riding uphill. Students track their progress—distance, time, speed, cadence and watts of energy generated—on a big-screen monitor, trying to improve their results over the course of the multi-week program. 

This program is held at existing youth institutions, such as elementary and middle schools, and is integrated into the normal school day. The program is designed to get participants on the bikes and moving, having fun in the process. Instructors guide participants through a series of workouts with varying terrain to provide students with a real experience. Since the program can be held indoors, we can deliver programming year-round.

Kids Riding Bikes started in Central Indiana and in 2014, impacted 20,000 youth.


How your contribution helps...

The goal of Nine13 Sports NW is to provide the Kids Riding Bikes program without any costs to participating schools.  Funds raised during this campaign will go to covering the costs of getting the project off the ground which includes equipment (bikes, trainers, computers, transportation, signage) and costs associated with delivering the program to schools.  

As of March 30th, there are already two Portland schools scheduled to host Kids Riding Bikes in May, and we are already planning programs in the 2015-16 school year.


Why this program matters...

Over the course of the next five years, our goal is to impact 80,000 community kids through this program. The equipment purchased through this campaign will be used to deliver the message of living an active lifestyle through cycling for years to come. Your contribution will help us promote health, wellness and exercise as we strive to combat childhood obesity and get kids moving on bicycles.

Portland has a vibrant cycling community with organizations that play important roles: providing safe routes to school (BTA), offering discounted or free bikes and helmets (Community Cycling Center) and promoting youth racing .  We are currently working with all these excellent non-profits. However, there is no organization in the area that provides that first step: working within the school system to put kids on bikes while providing a fun, interactive experience, no matter their prior experience with riding.  Kids Riding Bikes can play a crucial role in the larger cycling community, while promoting the overall mission to reduce childhood obesity.


Risks & Challenges

Childhood obesity has more than doubled in children and quadrupled in adolescents in the past 30 years. In 2012, more than one third of children were overweight or obese. Kids need to get moving. Kids Riding Bikes is a program designed to incorporate active movement and game play through computerized trainers. Nine13 Sports NW needs your help getting the necessary funding to start delivering the program to the Portland and Vancouver area.


Other Ways You Can Help

Donate equipment!  Do you have a laptop or 50-60" monitor that we can use for our programming?  Want to help organize a fundraising event? Do you have skills with branding our van with a vinyl wrap?  Do you have a product or item you think we could use in an auction?  If you have a skill, physical item or free tmime you think we could use, contact us. 

Volunteer!  As the program gets up and running we'll need volunteers to help facilitate different tasks such as promoting the program to area youth institutions, contacting potential corporate supporters and actually running the program at youth instutions, expos, etc.

Tell your friends about us!  Share this campaign and our information with anyone and everyone.  We need your help getting the word out about our program in the Portland/Vancouver community. Tell PE teachers, principals and PTAs about us!

Contact Charlie at cwarner@velohealth.org

story:
Hi Everyone,

I am Sanda, I'm burmese and one of the co-founders of BurmeseHearts.com . We aim to help learners and instructors connect around a range of subjects, from alphabet for kids to adult courses.

Myanmar may have many problems to solve and I believe that having a platform for skill-based and lifelong learning, where any content expert can be an instructor, including individuals, companies, publishers ,universities is solving a real problem.

The problem of highly unskilled workforce is not a surprise considering Myanmar was a closed country for decades. Currently there is not enough skilled employees in many fields in Myanmar as more and more international companies choose to set up operations there.


From BurmeseHearts.com , people can learn to build better relationship in family and society and to become part of a modern and increasingly more technical workforce. In our educational platform, we allow instructors to market, share and monetize their content and engage with new learners. With 3500 learners (as of 26 Dec) logging and 700K page views during  six-month, we today have 460 lessons for Myanmar people who want to learn a new skill.

We do help Myanmar people with our learning platform and our own budget. But our reach is limited to reach more Myanmar people with our little budget. We want to increase our support for those without education/skill in their neighborhoods and also make it easier for learners and instructors to message each other, to chat and share course materials and content.

There is no such e-learning platform for Burmese speaking where they can learn outside the university / school system with emphasize on individual self-paced lessons, book offline classes/workshops third parties , find online educational growing community (chat/social edtech network)   and a basic eCommerce shop (upcoming) to buy education related products.

Your contributions will help us:

(1) to fund a strategic advertising & sales campaign to spread the word about our education platform , reach 30-50K registered users, scale, refine marketing/ customer acquisition, on boarding instructors for Online-to-Offline (O2O)

(2) to offset the legal and filing fees necessary to establish our presence in Myanmar as an official Company. To achieve 500-700 courses created, setting up operations (hiring)  

Your contribution – no matter how big or small – will help us grow, and will help us help more learners achieve their academic goals.  

Thanks for your support! Stay in touch, and spread the word!

Help us get the word out about the BurmeseHearts campaign by sharing the project with friends and family. Follow @BurmeseHeartsPage on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter. Feel free to shoot us an e-mail us at learn@burmesehearts.com .


PERKS!

story:
Our World 2021 is a socioeconomic forum whose aim is to throw light on what could be our near future. We could just have limited to enlighten different key issues that are determinant now, but the real challenge is to know which are going to be the main issues in the future.


While we are living our daily life, we do not usually think about how society  would have been if a given event did not take place. We only think of what we have in front of us, just ignoring the environment surrounding us. We should be conscious that if we are living a determined lifestyle in a specific social frame, it is because there have been a numerous chain of event that led to where we find ourselves now. For that reason, there exist people who try to understand our current situation by looking at the past. Most of historians are able to interpret different events of world´s history in order to show the impact on our society. Almost everybody finds this interesting and useful, but there is a more serious challenge waiting us: the future. The challenge that we pose here is to forecast the main key issues regarding our lives in 2021. We want to hear from remarkable experts the most relevant hints in realtion to what could occur in a few years.



“The future has several names. For the weak, it is impossible; for the fainthearted, it is unknown; but for the valiant, it is ideal.” 
-  Victor Hugo



  We have identified three main issues concerning different areas that are going to influence our future directly: technology, Syria and China. For each area we are approaching different experts on these topics so that they can give us their opinion about that will, in some extend, directly determine the flow of history.


  • Technology: Technology nowadays is everywhere, it´s everything, and it is responsible for the development of our time. Recently, we are experiencing a global exponential growth, both in terms of economic  and social development. Technology is changing the way we behave. Our lives are so influenced by different devices, such as telephones or PCs,  that we are not able to get rid of  them, they are practically part of us. For this reason, we believe there are some questions concerning technology that should be approached so as to make people conscious of the possible future technological revolutions that may occur.

                              


  • Syria: Although this seems to be an actual conflict, the problems emerging from it are going to have effects for longer that we can imagine. What is going to happen with the millions of people escaping from the Middle East and searching for asylum in Europe? How is the armed racial conflict in Syria going to end? It si clear that many of these questionsremain unresolved and because of this, we would like to address the Syrian conflict as one of the most important factors regarding our future situation in 2021.

   


  • China: The first world economic power (in terms of PPP GDP) is growing nowadays at incredible speed. Apparently, the Asian giant is trying to liberalize its economy. Currently, we can observe how this country is opening more to the global markets and therefore, developing a more liberal economy both within the country and the rest of the world. But it seems that last year they suffered a process of economical deceleration, and is not growing as fast as was expected. What is going to happen with China? Is it going to be capable of taking the lead in world economic growth? Is China going to be able to keep ahead, or is going to succumb to the U.S.?

    







Why should I collaborate with OURWORLD2021?


This forum is a great opportunity to understand the complex problem presented while analysing the possible future outcomes of history.Unfortunately, we are aware that not every donor will be able to attend the congress. still, we believe anyone interested in these topics should be able to access the content that will be presented in the different talks held in the University of Navarre.For this reason, the most loyal contributors will have online live streaming access to the talks. It is a unique opportunity to see the future from the perspective of the most remarkable gurus of the economic growth of China, the impacts of Syrian conflict and the future of technology. Help us find solutions before it is too late...



Official sponsors:

story:
Hi there! My name is Scott Santens aka "2noame". I write a lot about the idea of universal basic income and actively advocate for its adoption to end poverty, reduce inequality, shrink bureaucracy, reform welfare, simplify the tax code, kickstart entrepreneurs,  grow productivity, accelerate innovation, and finally make our growing technological unemployment/underemployment work for us all (instead of only for some and against most like it is now).

To help spread the word and grow the discussion around the idea, the Universal Income Project has begun helping organize "hackathon" style meetups where people who want to make a difference in building momentum for basic income can gather together for a few days of brainstorming and mutual creation. This is called a Create-a-Thon.

The first ever Create-a-Thon for Basic Income took place last year in the Bay Area on November 13-15th, and the second is taking place this time in Los Angeles on April 15-17th. As one of the moderators of the /r/BasicIncome community on Reddit who helped sponsor the first Create-a-Thon, I'd like to see our community help sponsor it again.

Our goal is a simple one. Let's together raise $100-$500 in the next two weeks, to help cover the expenses of the Create-a-Thon. In doing so, /r/BasicIncome will be listed as one of the sponsors, and this will serve the dual purpose of both helping advance the adoption of basic income, and also gaining new members to our growing community.

For those who would like to help but just can't financially, please consider sharing this campaign, and also just simply learning about and discussing the idea of universal basic income with others.

#BasicIncome
