story:
Meet Lee:

Hi everyone, my name is Lee Stockner. I'm the creator of Occupational Octaves™.  As a child, I was diagnosed with Attention Deficit Disorder but also showed signs of talent at the piano. While struggling through mainstream educational and social challenges, I developed an identity immersed in music. At 15, I was a classical pianist and I began my life as a music educator. Ten years later I was teaching at a local music store and met a woman with her son who was on the Autism Spectrum. They were looking for piano lessons and with no special education training or experience, I offered to be his piano teacher. His mom helped me navigate the behavioral and communicative challenges of teaching with adaptations and he learned to play. As we continued, she encouraged me to work with more students on the Autism Spectrum because I was "a natural."

So, in 2007 I began working at schools for individuals severely affected by Autism in the Long Island area. By the time I was 27, I created the Special-Needs-User-Friendly language of music that would eventually become Occupational Octaves Piano™ because unlike my first student, many can't read traditional notation. Having already met parents of special learners who had unsatisfying experiences at music lessons, I knew the market was there for me to try and grow a local business. While developing a client base, I learned to identify the areas of communication, concentration, and interaction that were lacking for each student, which helped me learn numerous ways to adapt the piano lesson and support individual needs.

Over the years I posted videos of what my students were accomplishing, and people began reaching out to use the program themselves. I self-published my original curriculum to share my program and since then, hundreds of music educators, music therapists, occupational therapists, and special educators around the world have purchased the book series! My goal is to expand my curriculum to include many more instruments, starting with the drums, bass and guitar.

 
 

So where will your money go?

  • New and approved Occupational Octaves Piano books 1-3
  • Occupational Octaves™ books 4-8
  • Creating book 1 for Occupational Octaves™ Drums, Bass, and Drums
  • Marketing campaigns to expand the reach of Occupational Octaves™ and bring the program to as many special learners as possible.
  • Occupational Octaves™ Transitions - for students to seamlessly transition from the Special-Needs-User-Friendly language into reading traditional music notation.

 

Why you should care:

This New Language of Music has limitless potential. It allows people who can’t comprehend and/or properly use traditional music notation to play with ease and independence. The Special-Needs-User-Friendly approach allows a broad range of instructors, regardless of musical knowledge, to teach it and apply their own expertise to the platform. For example, an Occupational Therapist may use it help someone strengthen their fingers, a Special Educator may use it to help someone increase their attention span, and a Music Therapist may use it to target a broad range of non-musical goals. With Occupational Octaves™, students play right away, which captures the imagination. Imagination is the root of motivation, and our students are motivated!

Since numerous families and teachers I’ve worked with believe in the Occupational Octaves™ mission, many have given me permission to display some of our experiences. My YouTube, Facebook, and Instagram videos go back to days before even knowing that Occupational Octaves™ could expand to other instruments. I encourage you to watch the program and students evolve. I have spent almost every single day of the last decade working with people with Autism and other special needs at the piano. I live and breathe Occupational Octaves™. With employees ready to take the reins of my local NY based school, I’m ready to tackle every front of expanding!

Many families and teachers I’ve worked with believe in the Occupational Octaves™ mission and have given me permission to share our experiences. My YouTube, Facebook, and Instagram videos go back to beginning of my program. I encourage you to watch the program and students evolve. I have spent almost every single day of the last decade at the piano, working with people with Autism and other special needs. I live and breathe Occupational Octaves™ and I’m ready to tackle every front of expanding!

Occupational Octaves Curriculum/Training –

Facebook/YouTube: Occupational Octaves Piano

Instagram/Twitter: @OccOctavesPiano

NY Based School -

Facebook: The Occupational Octaves School of Music

Instagram: @OccOctavesSchool

Many families and teachers I’ve worked with believe in the Occupational Octaves™ mission and have given me permission to share our experiences. My YouTube, Facebook, and Instagram videos go back to beginning of my program. I encourage you to watch the program and students evolve. I have spent almost every single day of the last decade at the piano, working with people with Autism and other special needs. I live and breathe Occupational Octaves™ and I’m ready to tackle every front of expanding!
Occupational Octaves Curriculum/Training –
Facebook/YouTube: Occupational Octaves Piano
Instagram/Twitter: @OccOctavesPiano
NY Based School -
Facebook: The Occupational Octaves School of Music
Instagram: @OccOctavesSchool

story:
THE IDEA

Rough Cuts Pte Ltd is a television company that has been producing television shows for  the last 16 years. After directing 52 episodes of a children's series, we realized that children would learn to read early, if they were as engaged as they were with television. 

After 8 months of researching on the available technologies and speaking to parents and child educators, we had a ‘eureka’ moment. We came up with an idea to get kids engaged in books and away from tablets and phones. 

We decided to make an actual book with pages that they could turn but now have the words light up word for word as the book is read to them. 

Yes you heard correctly. Not a tablet. Not a phone but a book with hidden lights and sound inside each of its pages. 

BRINGING LIFE TO BOOKS

Children have a wild imagination. We designed a technology that would awaken that imagination so that through music, sound effects and voices that replicate the ones on cartoons, everything on the page came alive because they imagined it to come alive. 

But this wasn’t the bigger picture. 

The bigger picture was that not only did regular preschoolers struggle with learning how to read, there were the children who struggled with Dyslexia. 

We learnt that children with Dyslexia would benefit most from a book that read aloud to them and showed them what was being read at the same time! 

So now we had a book that engaged the kids and brought the words to life. The book highlights the words as it reads to them. Like singing a karaoke! All of their senses are aroused and they are now reading even before speaking as early as 1 years of age. 

Call us old fashion but as parents, we grew up with books that transported us to places we could only dream up. With this technology we hope that we can bring back the love for books in children and help kids with Dyslexia.

The big dream is to eventually make series of books with fascinating stories that will inculcate not just the love for reading but unleash the great big imagination in their little minds. 

Our children have young, pure, creative minds and they don't need to watch the television, phone or tablet to make a fairy fly or a dragon spit fire. Let them be the directors of their own movie in the books they read. 


THE BOOK    


·Multi-sensory experience through touch, visual and auditory activities

·Colorful, Read-Aloud book springs to life with voice and music

·Led powered, Self-lighting words as the book reads 

·Battery operated (Safe for children)

·Built to sharpen motor skills

·World’s first in read-along technology



This special book works with two unique functions, sound and light. An in-built audio and light system board achieves this. 

As the book reads, the words on the page are highlighted, synchronizing the sound with words, a fun way of teach your child to read on his own at the same time develop his motor skills.

The book also connects with child on different levels.

For instance pressing the play button activates the lights on the cover page, bringing the book to life. Pressing it plays music, as it would on an Mp3 player.

The narration of the stories will be done by voice over artiste with the accompaniment of music and sound effects. Think, Disney Read-Along Books with CDs that you pop into your car player but now all that in a book, in your child's hands.  



TECHNOLOGY TO HELP CHILDREN WITH DYSLEXIA

 

Dyslexia is an auditory/language problem, visual/perceptual problem, and often also a visual/motor (eye/hand) problem Educators have not been able to agree on what dyslexia really is. Some authorities believe that is strictly a language-processing problem that involves the distinguishing of sounds of letters. Others believe that it is a visual/perceptual problem since these children reverse words laterally as well as scrambling letters when they read and write.

After much study, experts have suggested some ways in which children that struggle with Dyslexia can recognize words:


EXPERT SUGGESTIONS

TECHNOLOGY

Motivate them

The technology in the book will engage them with its sound and light elements.

Read Aloud

The technology in the book will help them decode, and make it easy for them to understand the meaning.

Let younger children "pretend" to read

The technology in the book will encourage them to read the story aloud together.

Let them follow your voice

The technology shows them which word Is being read so they can mimic the reader.

Use print which is large

This book is catered to all preschoolers as such large prints will be inherent in the book.

If you have a computer, equip it with software that reads aloud

The technology in the book will not require them to go on the computer especially if they are at a younger age. This will allow parents to address Dyslexia as early as 21/2 to 3 years of age.

Use recorded books or audio books

This technology is just that.


WHAT WE NEED

We need to raise 40,000 USD for this prototype. A book of this nature, requires an actual working prototype. The money will be used to make it's working prototype. 


Phase 1: Feasibility Study, System Engineering and Cost Analysis: 
Activities: 
- Verify techonology available to achieve the result
- Component sourcing and part identifications possibility
- System block diagram establishment
- Certification requirement
- Cost analysis (establishment of optimistic and pessimistic scenario)

PRICE : 4350 USD


Phase 2EE: Electronic Engineering
Activities:
- Design electronic solution (schematic establishment)
- Design PCB layout
- Firmware programming
- Testing and refinement

PRICE : 18,550 USD


Phase 2ME: Mechanical Engineering
Activities: 
- Mechanical part design (holder, plastic)
- Raw Material selection and sourcing
- Assembly design and verification
- Moldflow verification
- Design for Manufacturing optimization
- Design for Assembly

PRICE : 15,550 USD

Phase 3: Prototyping
Activities: 
- Realize Plastic Part prototype
- Realize electronic part prototype
- Realize paper part prototype
- Assembly and test

PRICE : 1150 USD

GRAND TOTAL : 39,600 USD


SUMMARY

 "There is a cultural narrative about how electronic devices are pulling children away from books. In this busy screen dominated environment many children are simply not in the habit of reading, because their eyeballs are glued to their phones and ipads.Technophobes think we are raising a generation that doesn’t understand the value of literature.

How do we preserve the art of reading for pleasure? Do we even want to? We say a resounding yes, because reading for pleasure is the single biggest indicator of a child's success academically, more than social background or parents' education." 

Together, let us instil the love for books in our kids. 

                                                                                                                           - FORBES


WHAT ELSE

We have launched this new campaign to raise the funds necessary to help us pay for prototyping cost. Each dollar you donate will bring us closer in making the world's first KARAOKE BOOK for children.

Any extra funds we raise will go towards offsetting our operational cost.


OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

As always, we appreciate everything you do, if a monetary donation is not a possibility for you right now, please take a moment to share this campaign.

The more people that hear about us, the more likely we are to reach our goal and be able to develop our Techonlogy.

story:
Who Does This Benefit?

1) The first $1,500 raised is to purchase 2 laptops for Puku.co.za
"The principle aim of the Puku Children’s Literature Foundation, is to bridge both the literacy and the digital divide that confronts the vast majority of Southern African children, by developing dynamic and innovative programmes and projects to improve the quality of children’s books, educational and recreational materials in all Southern African languages. " http://puku.co.za/Pages/1/About

2) The remaining funds will be use to purchase books for 3 community projects in South Africa, so that children in poverty-stricken communities can have access to books in their local languages.


Who I Am and Why I Care

I'm an American writer, currently living in South Africa.  As I turn 45 this year, I can't help but reflect on my own life in comparison to the lives around me. I was so very lucky to be surrounded by books when I was little. From the Pokey Little Puppy and other Golden Books, to Just So Stories, and later to Nancy Drew mysteries and the entire Wizard of Oz collection (Ozma of Oz was probably my favorite.)

If those books had been any language other than English, I would have struggled hard to learn to read, and probably never developed a passion for reading. Reading should be a joy, not a chore.

Help me to help children of indigenous languages find their own passion for reading, by buying a couple much needed laptops for Puku.co.za, and by helping me purchase as many children's books as possible in indigenous languages to put into the communities where families cannot afford to buy them.

Too Much to Ask?

I used to think that $4.50 is not too much to ask of any one person, until I moved here to South Africa. The average domestic worker earns around $15.00 per day. A single book can cost a full day's wage. Most families, no matter what they want for their child's future, have to focus their income on food, bus or taxi fare, and medical expenses.

    Why Not Leave it to the Government?

    Good question! Sadly it's the same question we can ask every country where there are not enough funds, or too much red tape, or too many initiatives taking up all the time and money elsewhere. 

    It's easy to point out where the system fails these children. But I'd rather use my birthday to just do something about it: raise funds that I will use to directly benefit an organization dedicated to literacy, and to buy children's books in local languages for 3 community projects.

story:
NEW PERKS for the FINAL DAYS!


**be sure to check out the updates and gallery section above!

Make Culture Mobile!

Do you appreciate cultural attractions like museums, zoos, festivals and theaters in your community? In your state? Around your region? Across the country? Help us facilitate the country’s largest mobile platform for cultural organizations, Piggyback App!

Hello, my name is Pete Brown. I’m a former elementary teacher, turned arts administrator originally from Detroit, MI. For the past 12 years my family and I have lived in Indianapolis, IN and for nearly a decade I worked at a museum in town. During my time there I learned the ins and outs of our organization, and many others across the country.

As a former teacher, education was paramount in the roles I had at the museum. I was especially passionate about educating our visitors through a variety of multimedia outlets; audio, video, still images and text. Most teachers have heard of the multiple intelligences, the idea that all learners are different and require that information be presented in ways to suit their learning style. This concept, combined with the ever-growing use of mobile smart-device technology, led me to begin the search into creating a custom mobile app for our organization.

I quickly realized that this was unattainable for us due to the associated costs, the timeframe and our need for additional staffing. Our search for an easy and affordable solution kept leading us nowhere, so in 2013 I resigned to create a solution to the need that plagued so many cultural organizations across the country; the need to meet visitors on their phones and build a community platform for cultural organizations!


Version 1 of Piggyback App has been live for Apple, Android and Kindle devices since April of 2014, feel free to download and explore it! During that time we’ve worked with a dynamic assortment of organizations and individuals to fine-tune our features, mission and accessibility. With over a year of R & D under our belt, we are ready to update and launch Version 2 by the end of the year and we need your help!

While we strive to share and grow the largest mobile database of cultural attractions in our country, and keep it free, we will be incurring development, content creation and exploratory costs to make sure that we are doing the best service to the museums, zoos, festivals, historic sites and other cultural organizations from coast to coast.


Piggyback App will quickly become an interactive database of thousands of organizations which will be a one stop app for thousands of culture lovers looking to explore what is offered near them and as they start to plan their vacations and killer road trips! For cultural organizations, we’re a great cross marketing platform where venues large and small can rub elbows, learn from each other and share their missions, locations, contact information and more with users around the globe for FREE. Additionally, we offer extended service options for organizations looking to offer self-guided multimedia tours, ticket sales, events listings and more! Check out some of the testimonial videos and photos in our GALLERY section! 

Piggyback is the one free mobile app solution that will bring our nation’s cultural attractions to your fingertips. With our new updates in place we will foster an even more fluid and accessible experience to our users and cultural organizations alike.

Awesome Gear For Your Support!

In order to develop and update our platform, continue to build our extensive database and reach out to organizations across the country, our goal is to raise at least $7,500.

The perks from this fundraising campaign are stellar; there’s truly something for everyone! Please take a look. From custom Piggyback headphones and t-shirts to pint glasses and gift packs, there are a bunch of items that can help make your culture exploring more comfortable! Heck, you can even sponsor the organization of your choice to receive access to additional services from our team such as the ability to sell tickets, create self-guided tours, share program/event information and more! Anyone who helps support us financially will also be getting some love on social media and our website too!


In the event that we don’t reach our full fundraising goal, we will apply any raised funds directly to support the growth of our platform to whatever extent it can help. If we blow out goal out of the water, we'll be able to enhance our database and user experience even more! Either way, our mission won’t change, nor will our services for cultural organizations, they’ll just be slightly delayed or expedited!  

The Impact

As of today, cultural attractions can either offer a custom mobile app or not. The end. Only the top 1-3% of our nations 10,000+ cultural organizations can afford to do that; the others simply can’t. Piggyback App is setting out to balance the scales and bring them all together!

Instead of downloading an app for each place you visit, if they offer one, you can download Piggyback to learn about them all! No more filling up your phone’s home screen with countless apps that you download at the venue, use only once and then delete.


Since 2014 we’ve gotten a great response during meetings, demos, conferences and from folks that we’ve never met who have tried us out. With over 1,000 users and tens of thousands of screen views, from the USA and abroad, with our current assortment of regional organizations, that number is certain to grow as our platform does!

In this day and age of arts funding on the decline, please consider taking a step to educate the world about our nation’s rich cultural offerings by supporting the growth of Piggyback App.

What Else Can You Do?

Please take a few seconds to share our campaign via email and social media to all of your culture-loving friends, family and colleagues! Not only are we already fired-up to see these updates become a reality, we are also fired-up to connect the public at large with all that our country’s museums, zoos, historical sites, festivals and more have to offer them!

story:
Our Mission

  1. Education
    We aim to teach as many people as we can find the basics of lampowrking all across the country giving them the basic knowledge to start their journey. We also want to teach shop owners the importance of supporting local artists and the local economy. 
  2. Web Television
    We will be launching our own T.V. Show on Youtube and our blog highlighting our travels and interviewing some of North Americas greatest glass blowers.
  3. Documentary Film
    Over The course of our 5 year travels we will be making a 2 hour documentary film on American Glass Culture highlighting American pipe making and American glass sculpting. 

How It will work: WE'RE GOING MOBILE!
My wife has graciously agreed to let me sell our family home and buy a bus to call home for the next 5 years. With your contribution we will be converting our Motor Coach into a home/mobile glass education center/film production vehicle, and hitting the road for 5 years covering the United States and Canada.

Where your funding goes

  • Educational tools: With a target class size of 8 students per 3 day class we are going to have to buy 8 workstations worth of torches, tools, and PPE 
  • Filming Equipment: You probably do not want to watch shaky cell phone or web cam video as much as we do not want to sell our home to make a sub par end result. 
  • Fuel: With our goal or relocating every 14-21 days we anticipate we will consume about 3,000-5,000 gallons of Sustainable Bio Diesel per yer.
  • Educational Materials for shop owners: We are going to be mass producing an information packet for local shop owners to help educate them on the importance of supporting local artists and how it helps increase their sales and support the local economy. Each information package is going to cost us between $12 & $25

Changing Lives

We don't need to explain to you the state of the economy. In the end we hope to impact as many lives as possible and give them the basic beginning skills to change their situation and help start them on the road to self sufficiency through glass.  In the early days of the United States, every colony had a glass blower to produce glass for the community. It was a working business model then, and it can work now. Together we can change lives one piece of glass at a time.

    Risks & Challenges

    Selling nearly everything you own and setting off on a 5 year adventure to help change the lives of others comes with many challenges. When your home has wheels and those wheels brake, When your home has wheels and is constantly moving and you need to get mail, When your teaching lampworking and your classroom needs to be mobile, oxygen generation, kilns, etc. There are many risks, and many challenges we expect to have to overcome on this journey, but we have full faith that with your help both in your contributions and your hospitality along the road we can help change lives together.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

    • We are partnering with some of the largest RV resorts in North America to ensure we have a place to park our wheels, but not everywhere that people want to learn have an in network RV resort. Maybe some day we can camp in your back yard for 3 days while we run a class.
    • You could share this campaign on your facebook and other social media pages to help draw attention from others who might be able to contribute.
    • Maybe you have something in your collection you made that you want to donate to our mobile store front to help keep fuel in the tank.
    • If every glass blower in the USA donated only $5 we would reach our goal in 1 day.
story_txt:
Our Mission

 


EducationWe aim to teach as many people as we can find the basics of lampowrking all across the country giving them the basic knowledge to start their journey. We also want to teach shop owners the importance of supporting local artists and the local economy. 

Web TelevisionWe will be launching our own T.V. Show on Youtube and our blog highlighting our travels and interviewing some of North Americas greatest glass blowers. 


Documentary FilmOver The course of our 5 year travels we will be making a 2 hour documentary film on American Glass Culture highlighting American pipe making and American glass sculpting.  

 How It will work: WE'RE GOING MOBILE!My wife has graciously agreed to let me sell our family home and buy a bus to call home for the next 5 years. With your contribution we will be converting our Motor Coach into a home/mobile glass education center/film production vehicle, and hitting the road for 5 years covering the United States and Canada.   Where your funding goes
  Educational tools: With a target class size of 8 students per 3 day class we are going to have to buy 8 workstations worth of torches, tools, and PPE   Filming Equipment: You probably do not want to watch shaky cell phone or web cam video as much as we do not want to sell our home to make a sub par end result.  
 Fuel: With our goal or relocating every 14-21 days we anticipate we will consume about 3,000-5,000 gallons of Sustainable Bio Diesel per yer.

Maybe some day we can camp in your back yard for 3 days while we run a class.
You could share this campaign on your facebook and other social media pages to help draw attention from others who might be able to contribute. 

Maybe you have something in your collection you made that you want to donate to our mobile store front to help keep fuel in the tank. 

If every glass blower in the USA donated only $5 we would reach our goal in 1 day.

story:
[Developing a state of the art teaching facility for drummers, musicians and percussion ensembles]

Hello, I'm Kevin Dean. I recently learned that the business that currently houses my teaching studio is moving their enterprise to a new facility and selling the building. Soon. Luckily, I found a new location. A like-minded creative thinker is expanding our local arts community with a vision of making our city a better place to live, by renovating an old building called the Gear Factory. I want in on the ground floor (basement floor actually) of this new opportunity. 

Change is good. I need a change too. As it stands, my career and student base are growing, but my studio space is not. In order to do more amazing things for my students and the community I need a major upgrade. 

For the future of this endeavor, In addition to my private lessons, I want to offer -

1) parent/child lessons so Dad and son and or Mom and daughter can learn and grow together musically and intellectually.

2) group lessons for several drummers (anywhere from 5 to 15 players),

3) coaching sessions for high school percussion sections, ensembles, and marching band drum lines,

4) my continued services to volunteer for physically and mentally challenged individuals by inviting them to a new spacious, professional atmosphere instead of going on location.

5) 24 hour access facility with no noise constraints for band rehearsals and recording sessions (I'm in four projects at this time)

6) opportunities to sublet my studio to drum teachers, piano teachers, music teachers and musicians who are in need of space for limited use.

7) an inspirational and spacious environment for drummers and percussion groups to rehearse and perform for live shows and recitals.

8) multi-track recording for student demos and auditions as well as recording studio tracks for my collaborations and songwriting endeavors.

9) drum repairs and refurbishing.

10) drum circles and rhythm workshops.

In order to provide all of these services and offer a state of the art studio, so I can provide the most comprehensive teaching experience possible, I need the following gear:

soundproofing/curtains/acoustical tiles etc., shelving,  a closet, carpet/padding, new drum kits, hardware, cymbals, sticks, heads, mallets, percussion, paint supplies, mini fridge, microwave, table, 6 chairs (4 in the room, 2 for waiting area), widescreen TV/bracket, PA system, Speakers, powered monitors, microphones for 2 full drum kits, xlr cables, 1/4" cables, mic stands/clips…

[ALL PERKS ARE TRANSFERRABLE]

story:
The main ideas of the project:
 

  • Teach children who cannot afford music instrument lessons
  • Play music where it is not common to hear classical music performances
  • Support students who would be willing to do so

If you are interested in supporting this, please do contact me.

story:
Coaches Briana O'Dowd and David Stanek

We will be traveling (on our own expense - see picture of purchased tickets) to Turkey, Romania, and Hungary between November 22nd and December 6th.  We are former players, current professional coaches holding NSCAA and UEFA licenses.  We both coach at a premier soccer clubs in the SF Bay Area and co-own a small soccer business.  We have been to Scotland, Ireland, and England visiting youth soccer academies and now we are doing the same in Eastern Europe.
While in Hungary, Romania and Turkey we will use your donations to distribute hundreds of soccer balls to the children in and around the established UNHCR refugee camps throughout our tour, especially outside of Budapest .
A simple round, inflated soccer ball will bring joy, sport, distraction, exercise, ownership, teamsmanship, learning, creativity, and sense of self worth to the children inhabiting these camps.

We need your contribution 

Balls will cost between ten and fifteen US dollars.  If we have to import, with shipping we plan that each ball will cost under $20.  The dollar is strong, so if we merely crowd source a few hundred dollars, we will simply purchase balls locally (for about $5/ea.).  However, if we crowd source thousands, then we will need to bulk order and the price per unit will change (see Risks & Challenges below).
Special Note: We have enabled the "In Demand" feature so that we can continue raising funds once our campaign is over.  Any such funds will go to purchasing balls and cleats for underprivileged Oakland, CA youth.  Thank You!
If we raise:
- $0 we will fit as many deflated balls into our suitcases as possible and hand them out.
- $100 we will purchase as many balls as we can during our travels, and hand them out. *See perks for $100 donation.
- $500 we will purchase between 50-100 balls, inflate them and hand them out at various locations. *See perks for $500 donation.
- $1000 we will purchase 100-200 balls, inflate them and hand them out over multiple days at various locations. *See perks for $1000 dollar donation.
- $2000 we will purchase a small air compressor, hundreds of balls, inflate them and hand them out at multiple places and donate the compressor to a deserving and needy person upon departure.
- Anything over $2000 you get the picture - more smiling children and one happy owner of an air compressor.
-If for some reason this crowd source goes viral we will use the extra money to buy shoes and other needed materials for the children of the refugee camps (there are only so many soccer balls we can purchase and receive - see below).
We are going to Budapest, Istanbul, and throughout Romania to visit youth soccer teams and take in the culture.  However, we want to donate our time and energy to something we feel (and hopefully YOU feel) will have a positive impact on the migrant youth that may not fully grasp the gravity of their situation.  We are asking for your financial help in doing so and in turn we are volunteering our time and "boots on the ground."
Wherever we go YOU will be an ambassador for the US and for soccer.

The Impact

If you've played soccer, or even if you haven't you may understand the community, sportsmanship, camaraderie, exercise and fun involved in the sport.  I personally cannot imagine being a child in a fenced off tent city, but the small gift of a new soccer ball can bring joy to the face of a child, distract them from the reality of a distressful situation and help them interact with one another in a positive way.

We will film the events so that you can see your donations at work. 

The reason we know soccer is a universal language is because we have both played all over the world.  Currently we coach players, some of whom are from the inner city of Oakland.  Our small business - California Soccer Solutions, LLC - consistently donates time and soccer skill building sessions and camps to under privileged players here in the San Francisco Bay Area.

Soccer levels the socio economic, political and cultural playing fields.

Risks & Challenges

Our biggest risk is bulk ball delivery.  As stated above; should we only raise hundreds of dollars then we will source balls locally and they will cost between five and ten American dollars each.  However, if we raise thousands of dollars, planning and taking delivery of equipment in a foreign country can be tricky.  We would most likely source a German or British based distributor and have them shipped to our rented apartment in Budapest.
Currently we are exploring the following options:
-can our current equipment supply company ship to Hungary?
-can a club we visit connect us with a local distributor?
-cost of shipping hundreds of balls ourselves.
-local sports equipment distributor pre-orders.
-websites like lovellworldsoccerstore.com and others. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't afford to donate a few dollars, we understand!  Please forward this link to your soccer team, your friends, your family and others empathetic to the Syrian children migrants.  Thank you!

story:
Mo:
Hello,

my name is Mohammad Aldawi (Mo for my friends) and I'm from Palestine (Westbank). I'm 18 years old and I have 2 brothers and 2 sisters. My father Osama is a worker in a company that produces tea and coffee and my mother Ahrar takes care of my two younger siblings.

I graduated from school (High school) this year with 93.2% in the scientific branch. My dream is to study medicine in Germany in order to become a doctor to be able to help my people.

Unfortunately my father can't pay the 8.200 € (~9,170 $) that are required for the German studying visa. These are the estimated living costs in Germany for one year that I have to provide beforehand. My father only earns 300 € (~330 $) per month and with this little money he has to support all of us.

But he will lend approximately half of the money from a friend if I can get half of the money myself.

Please help make my dream come true so I can become a doctor.


My story

When I was born I found myself in a refugee camp in Nablus living with 10 persons including my mom, dad and two siblings. We lived in a simple house containing just two rooms and my father had no work at the time to feed us. There were a lot of problems in our camp. People were fighting with the soldiers to be free and a lot of houses were lost and their owners with them :(.

This is not my refugee camp because I do not have pictures of it at the time. But this is what a refugee camp looks like after clashes with Israeli soldiers.


We were lucky – we survived and so did our house. We are still living in it with 7 people. When I was 5 years old - the time when children usually start school here – I couldn’t go to school because Israeli soldiers entered the camp and a lot of people were killed. But my mum taught me at home and during this year I learned to read simple words.


For as long as I can remember I had the dream to become a doctor. My father even used to call me Doctor Mohammad sometimes and even introduced me to other people like this. I think he always supported this dream because he wanted one of his kids to be able to study in order to get a good job. A chance he never had.

However, I didn't know that it's so difficult to make your dream come true when you live in a refugee camp. But I believe that nothing is impossible. You just have to work hard to get your chance :). There are many poor children like me thinking that their dream will come true easily, I used to hear them pointing to their future car or house…

If I could with your help make my dream come true I would really like to help making their dreams come true as well.

I got to know Mo during my 3 month long internship in Nablus. He is such a kind, generous, hardworking and responsible person. He is already taking care of most of his expenses himself in order to lighten his father’s burden to provide for the family. In Palestine it is really hard to find a job and even if you have one, they are not very well paid. He is now fighting for his dream working 11 hours per day in a small restaurant earning only 7.50 € per day. Yes, that’s no mistake. He only earns 7.50€ per day! Nevertheless he still finds the time to do a German language course at the Al Amal center in Nablus. Mo has always been a very good student –since grade 8 he has always been among the top 3 students of his class (1 class = 50 students). And in grade ten (07/2013) he was given the certificate of Excellency for the best student in school.


Since then he also found the time to work as a volunteer every Friday and two months in the summer at the Madeed Center for Psychiatry. Only now he has stopped to be able to work more hours for his dream.
Once in Germany he is also going to apply for different schoolarships. Unfortunately you can only apply for a schoolarship after studying in Germany for at least one year (so you have a record of  achievements). If that doesn't work out, he will finance his future years by working beside his studies/working a side job.
A lot of smart young adults like him have no future in Palestine. They are surrounded by borders. If they want to travel by plane they first have to travel to Jordan. Medical supplies are limited and study fees are difficult to provide, even though living costs are fairly low.


We have the hope that if everyone who sees this just gives one Euro, he will be able to gain the money for the Visa.

His visa interview is on the 12th of December 2015. Since raised funds take about 15 days until they are transferred he only has until the 29th of November to raise the money. Please help to make his dream come true.

If you cannot help financially, please please forward this campaign to your friends and family. By helping him you will also encourage many other young Palestinians to follow their dream. Everything can be possible with friendly helping hands and your support.

Interested if everything worked out? We will also keep you updated on this page after the campaign ended.

story:
Through offering elementary English lessons as well as mindfulness, yoga, dance, and physical activity classes for Syrian refugee children, I Move Foundation provides Syrian refugee children with a chance to heal, to learn, and to strive for a better future.

Physical movement,yoga,and(breathing-based) meditationoffer the most effective means to treat the mental health of refugees and survivors who deal withPost Traumatic Stress Syndrome (PTSS), depression, and anxiety.

The foundation completely relies on periodic or incidental contributions by donors, sponsors, and individuals who make financial contributions to enable the continuation of our activities in enabling the disadvantaged children to thrive. 

We assure you that 100 % of your donations will be spent on children's education and mental well-being. Our pledge to our donors is to keep our overhead below the average in order to spend your donations as efficiently as possible. 

Donate to I Move Foundation today and help us achieve a better future for Syrian children.

story:
Hello, my name is David and I am here to tell you about the project “Next Great Writer”.  As you have probably witnessed, children have the largest, wildest imaginations, ripe for writing and full of creativity.  Yet writing sometimes takes a back seat in education. We aim to help youth students excel as writers and prepare them to be great writers by combining an exclusive detailed writing curriculum tailored specifically to their age.  No one else is doing anything like this right now and we feel uniquely qualified to roll out this program.  That is why “Next Great Writer” holds such a strong place in our society.

So you may be wondering… What is the Next Great Writer??

Next Great Writer is a rare opportunity for children between the ages of 13 and 18 years of age to write a book about something that they are passionate about. The Next Great Writer program is a Nonprofit Organization that provides kids with the necessary tools, skills, and guidance to successfully write their 1st book. Though our program is online based we will be interactive with our students through our regular webinars, chat boards, and emails. Along the 9-month writing part of the program we will guide our students from chapter one all the way until they have a completed manuscript for publishing and contests. After their book is completed, we help polish their book and if the students want their book will be submitted into the Next Great Writer Awards contest.  Entry into the program and contest is free for all dedicated participants.  Not only will this teach children the joys of writing but the resilience of going through the process and the reward that will follow, seeing their book in its final format.

The goal of this campaign is to reach like-minded people for collaboration, raise money in exchange for early access and rewards, and we also want to spread the word.  The more people we can get signed up for the “Next Great Writer” the more functional and successful it will be.  So this campaign will give you the basics on our efforts and progress.  Beyond that we encourage you to ask us questions, donate and get involved.  We developed “Next Great Writer” for your benefit, so enjoy!  We believe we are really onto an easier way to get kids excited about writing, while enjoying their innovative efforts.

Do you ever think about helping your child write something they can be proud of?

Do you see your child enjoying writing but don’t know where they can take the next step?

Are you interested in helping your child get published but don’t have the time?

If you answered, “Yes” to any of these questions, you may want to keep reading…

With the contribution of $1, $5, or even $100 you will receive some really cool perks; cash contributions of all sums are accepted. This is just the beginning of an awesome journey, and you are welcomed to come on board. But wait, why not let your friends in on this, share this with them through word of mouth, emails and social media and have them do the same!

Our Success So Far…

The Next Great Writer program will be led and managed by David (d. E.) Rogers. He is also the author of nine novels himself.  He will be leveraging all his knowledge and experience to make this program memorable for all of the youth participants.  Mr. Rogers has also directed several short films. In addition to his writing accolades, d. E. is a Stanford University-certified project manager; and has attended the University of Notre Dame for executive leadership and management and the New York Film Academy for film production.

His enormous skill set will be a very valuable asset in ensuring the success of the program. Other management and staff members will be brought on as we grow and build this amazing nonprofit organization.  High caliber writers, authors, and communications professionals will surround the youth attending this program.  This will be the opportunity of a lifetime for the children to grow and nurture their skills.

More about the Issue:

America is failing in literacy. Our reading and writing levels are below average and decreasing each year. With reading and writing going hand in hand the Next Great Writer program will make students increase their literacy skills. In our popular culture we reinforce the idea that WRITING A BOOK is hard, time consuming and sometimes not worthwhile. We're out to change that fallacious idea one “Next Great Writer” at a time! Help us establish this initiative to serve people in need of a solution. As little as a $1 donation a “Next Great Writer” student will have the opportunity to accomplish something that they will be proud of for the rest of his or her life. Empower us to make this vision a reality with a donation to this project today!

Who:

Amazon Best Selling Author and a publisher program lead: David (d. E.) Rogers

COMING SOON TO THE TEAM: YOU!

When:

The 9-month writing process

September 2016 Lessons and writing

 October 2016 - Complete Chapter 1

November 2016 - Review work and write

December 2016 - Review work and write

January 2017 - Review work and write

February 2017 - Review work and write

March 2017 - Review work and write

April 2017 - Review work and write

May 2017 - Finish and Polish Books

How:

We truly appreciate each and every donation, no matter what it may be. As a thank you we are offering various perks including:

·  Having your name featured on our website

·  Getting a personal thank you video from the youth who attend our program

·  Having your name listed as a team member in the material given to the children

·  Exclusive updates on events and the books being published

·  Have an opportunity to buy the children’s books before anyone else

·  We can even make a public donation announcement at our first group meeting

·  And much more!

Why:

We cannot raise this money without you; we need your support!

Your generous funding will allow us to host projects, which raise awareness of youth writing issues across the world. All of the funding will go towards launching this programs initiative. Assisting in education and lending a voice to youth are our main priority. The funds will also assist us with the cost of further development of our organization for further programs. The plans for the funds are to help reach all the children possible, outreach to the schools, purchase computers, software, writing books, other reference material, and for hiring staff which includes editors and special guest speakers.

The “Next Great Writer” needs pledging but above all it needs your attention and interest! If you love this project as much as we do then please take a moment to click on one of our social media buttons (Facebook, Twitter and YouTube at the bottom of the page). Help us spread the word and get things started!

Other Ways to Help

For me to bring my vision to life, I need your support!

If you aren't able to make a monetary donation, but would like to contribute to the campaign mission, there are plenty of other ways to help!

Volunteer

We will be looking for people to help edit and read our books throughout the process. But you can also volunteer at any youth writing initiative program as we are all working towards the same goal.

Teach someone else about the benefits of writing programs for youth

At its core, this campaign is about helping youth write. If you're in a position to teach someone else how to better view youth writing - do it! You are contributing to this campaign by passing on the awareness.

Spread the word

You can contribute your popularity by telling your friends and family about this campaign. The success of this campaign is directly correlated with the number of people who view this page. If you can increase that number, you are making a tangible contribution to the mission.

We feel so grateful to everyone who has taken the time to read our campaign and for those who contributed what they could to make a difference and helping us spread the word.  We have spent the last few months working hard to bring our vision to life in this campaign and it was worth every minute thanks to all our generous supporters.  Please know your efforts, even the smallest, don’t go unnoticed.  We will continue to keep you posted on what your donation helped us achieve.  You are part of our “Next Great Writer” family.

Old school?  No Problem!

For those of us who don't like making donations over the Internet, please feel free to contact me via email: Contact@NextGreatWriter.com and I will provide you with a mailing address to send check or money order to.  I will post your contribution on the campaign with your name and I will deliver whatever perk you would like.

If you wish to contact us:

Website: www.NextGreatWriter.com

Our Social Media Connections:

ü  Twitter: https://twitter.com/NextGreatAuthor

ü  Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Next-Great-Writer-Inc-...

ü  YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCGhD0Wj1bKkLiV...

Contact Information

Name: David Rogers

1-888-258-7775

E Mail: Contact@NextGreatWriter.com

If you have thoughts or would like to discuss a collaboration or sponsorship, we would love to hear from you, please feel free to contact us at Contact@NextGreatWriter.com

story:
Mission:

The mission of Treehouse Learning is to provide a safe, wholesome, and natural environment to inspire children through holistic and well-balanced curriculums. Our goal is to emphasize the Fine arts, Nature and establish an enthusiasm for learning through educational and social play.

Treehouse Learning provides an alternative social and learning experience at the American Czech-Slovak Cultural Center(ACSCC). The center is a multicultural club that welcomes all races, religions and ethnicities. We are family oriented and inspire young minds with creative activities, teachers, artists and mentors. 

Donations will help us: 

    • Maintaining small class sizes 
    • Teacher Educational Workshops, Specialty Teacher’s and Curriculum expansion
    • Property upgrading, Cleaning & Painting,
    • Remodeling the outdoor play area
    • Financial Assistance program are available families will be approved on an individual basis.

Every & Any Donation Helps!

The Impact:

Your contribution will help us expand our community of teacher’s, parent’s and community members. We make a difference in the way children learn and grow and show them how communities work together to create a greater good and support each other, both physically and mentally.

  1.  We are creating a child focused alternative educational system, free from testing requirements. Children are assessed based on their growth, mind, body and spirit, not numerical data.
  2. With our guidance, children learn how to understand, admire, and appreciate themselves, their peers and their environment.
  3. It is important that children develop good values and a strong moral compass.
  4. We insight a deeper connections to the world and the community.

Other Ways You Can Help:

We accept contributions of all shapes and sizes...<3

Tell your friends, family, coworkers and acquaintances how Treehouse Learning is REVOLUTIONIZING EDUCATION!

story:
Why This Campaign?

Here at ISCE, we recognize the gravity of the campus date rape culture plaguing students across the US. We want to make college campuses as safe as possible for all students who work so hard to attend them. In order to shift student sexual interactions norms from the outdated standard of “No Means No” to “Yes Means Yes,” society as a whole will have to work together to increase awareness.

To address this issue head on, we have developed a family of apps to facilitate affirmative consent.   See http://protectequalsrespect.com

A modern day issue demands a modern day solution. These apps hope to change the context of these encounters and develop an environment in which asking for consent is standard.

To combat this issue, we will need your help! We are asking for contributions to help distribute these apps to as many students as possible at no cost to the users. We hope that as more people start to change their practices/assumptions, we can make campus date rape a thing of the past.


What is We-Consent™?

WE-CONSENT™  is a simple app that records a video consisting of four brief segments totaling approximately 20 seconds of two people stating their affirmative consent to physical interaction. More important than the actual documentation of consent is the conversation trigger that the opportunity for documentation provides. 

When the WE-CONSENT™  App is present on one or both prospective partners' phones, this means that an easy opportunity for documentation of consent is close at hand.  The prospective partners need to decide whether or not to make use of the App.  The discussion about that decision is context for a direct discussion about affirmative consent itself.  Triggering such discussions is the major goal of the WE-CONSENT™  App. 


How You Can Help

ISCE.edu makes the WE-CONSENT™ App and its companion the WHAT-ABOUT-NO™ App available without cost to its members. (The WHAT-ABOUT-NO™ app is the reciprocal - a way for an individual to document that he/ she is not giving consent.)  Individuals access the apps by becoming members of the Affirmative Consent Division of ISCE (these memberships are $5/person annually).  Although this seems like a circuitous route to provide students with the app, this is the best and most practical means by which we may provide iPhone users with it, since Apple refuses to list the app in the iTunes store.

Our plan is to provide the apps to as many students as possible at no cost to them – which we can only do with the support of generous folks such as you. Our expectation is that having the apps on their phone will trigger the necessary discussions among young people -- discussions that by changing the culture will, in turn, help to ameliorate and prevent the growing problem of acquaintance sexual assaults on college campuses.

The Impact

Affirmative Consent is expected to become the prevailing standard on American college and university campuses over the next few years.  It is already the legal standard in both California and New York.  Providing the apps to students without cost removes a potential barrier to generating widespread use.  Like the measles vaccine, success does not depend on 100% adoption -- but rather, once a significant plurality has the app and is making use of it, the desired effects occur as a matter of course.

Please join us by helping give college students the tools they need to facilitate this significant shift in social attitudes and behaviors.

What is ISCE.edu?

ISCE is a 501(c)(3) organization, established in 1999, focused on educational research. Prior to this year our focus was researching complex social systems and promulgating such research through our journal E:CO (http://emergence.org), books, and conferences.  In addition we operate an on-line research library (http://epi-search.com).

The launch of the Affirmative Consent Division is augmented and supported by the past 15 years of our research - namely that societal or organizational change is unlikely to come about unless there first occurs change in the context for the desired action. Our focus is on the tools that assist in changing context. 

We believe that the provision of apps such as WE-CONSENT™ and others in the app family we are developing are tools which can result in just such a contextual change.  But to truly have impact the apps must be widely deployed in any given college or university community -- and to accomplish this we need your help.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the Word!!!  Send people to http://protectequalsrespect.com

    Tell as many people as possible about this campaign and about the Apps.

story:
Short Summary

The United States has a maternity care crisis; a rising maternal death rate, a national cesarean section rate hovering at 33%, and an infant mortality rate more than double that of Sweden, Japan, Portugal, Finland, Norway, and the Czech Republic. At the same time, there has been a tremendous decline in attendance at childbirth classes and an abundance of birth information online. This has led to many women receiving inaccurate information at best.  

When playing Down the Canal, learners are engaged in what they are discovering while having fun. This encourages not only retention of information, but an excitement and desire to want to know more.

This game will revolutionize the childbirth education experience. Childbirth educators can use it as part of their class series, doulas can share it with clients, and teachers can use it in the classroom. It allows for a personal and individual childbirth education when access to classes is a hardship. The game has 240 questions about pregnancy, birth, breastfeeding and more. 

By contributing to this fundraising campaign, you will be assisting in the spread of accurate information about birth, breastfeeding, birthing options and the newborn. Spreading this information is how we can truly have an impact on the demand for normal birth. 

During the testing phase, I received positive feedback from many birth professionals including doulas and childbirth educators, and from expectant parents.  From one childbirth educator: "While having fun, the game engages couples in a relaxed atmosphere." From one expectant parent: "Questions were great, brought a lot of good conversation. It's good to learn and review."

At the LamazeICEA conference Down the Canal was well received.  Attendees loved the colorful, inviting game board.  During one activity attendees use the conception and pregnancy cards to invoke discussion!!  There is a demand for Spanish translation. Many childbirth educators see the value in play, even for adults. The woman who won a FREE game at the raffle said, "Of all the things to win, I was hoping to win the game. I'm really excited."

Check out our website DowntheCanal.com and like our Facebook page.

About Me

It has always been important to me to educate expectant families, and young men and women about the birth process. It is a normal physiological event that has become feared rather than revered.  My desire is for people to play this game and become hungry for more knowledge about birth and beyond.

I am a visionary and an activist. I’ve been a postpartum doula, and an advocate for normal birth, since 1991. During my career I have trained hundreds of doulas and have served hundreds of families. It is my passion and my calling.

I am on the leadership team of Citrus County Birth and Beyond Professional Network and I serve on the Board of the Florida Breastfeeding Coalition. I am a founding member of the Coalition for Improving Maternity Services (CIMS) and served on its leadership team for two years.


What We Need & What You Get

I am raising funds to manufacture this game in the United States. My goal is to produce 1,500 games, at a cost of $25,000. This includes full production of the board, box, seven card sets, game pieces, dice, and directions along with game packaging and shipping.

I received quotes from several companies, and found one that is a good fit. The four prototypes I had made are being shared with educators and doula trainers who are excited about the game and all its uses. 

I have a launch plan in place and intend to initially target birth professionals. After my successful launch in this market, I will then pursue classrooms, websites geared toward pregnant Moms, and retail. I plan to sell the game at birth and health conferences as well as educational trade shows. I will also leverage social media by networking online as well as creating a presence through blogging. I have met and networked with hundreds of birth professionals during my 20 year career. I can leverage these relationships to build an affiliate program which will quickly increase sales of the game.  I also plan to sell to clinical providers for use in their waiting room. Additionally, I see this game in some of the major childbirth organizations' online stores and in catalogs that feature childbirth education tools.

I am anticipating attendance at the Game Manufacturers Association show in 2016. I am planning my calendar for the 2016 year of birth related and women's health conferences.

All funds collected will go toward manufacturing. No amount is too little. It takes a village to raise a child, and you are part of that village. 

The Impact

Here are some birth statistics that definitely need to change through consumer demand

  • The U.S. National cesarean rate hovers close to 33% and varies between states and among hospital. For example: in Florida two hospitals had a 62% rate in 2013!!
  • 1970 there was a 5.5% rate. Rates rose through 1989, then dipped slowly. 1998 rates began to rise then level off to the 33% range where they are today. The questions I would ask ;
1)Are women’s bodies broken? 
2) How many of these surgeries are medically necessary? 
3)What trends and factors are contributing to this alarming rate of birth by surgery?
 4) Do women and families know their rights and all options available to them in birth?
  • Many women have limited or no access to prenatal care and education. Let’s bring it to them!!!
  • Family’s choices in birth are dictated by insurance and availability to all options including birth centers and home.
  • Geography determines whether a woman can utilize a midwife or have an out of hospital birth, as laws vary state to state.

We can do better in the USA, where we have the resources and technology to save lives. Optimal care in childbirth includes evidence, provider wisdom, and parental choice and circumstances.

Consumers who are educated about birthing options, benefits and risks of tests and procedures, and birth terminology and process have the power to choose from an informed position.

Down the Canal is packed with information and resources, and allows for easy access to evidence-based information. The game brings the necessary resources to families in a fun-filled way. Theories state that when people are engaged in play while learning information is more likely to be retained.

I have been a childbirth professional for more than twenty years, and my experience has shown me that education can shift outcomes.  This game will make it easier to put the information out there for the taking.  I have great connections in this field, and many colleagues are ready and waiting to become affiliate marketers for Down the Canal. 

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge I might face once I have been funded is continuing to seek new locations to sell the game. It is all about the marketing and sales strategy. I have hired a virtual assistant to support me with this.  And will continue to seek the necessary support to bring this game to market.  As a visionary, my ideas are not enough. The action plan really matters. I am determined to see this through, no matter what. 

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand that you may be as excited as I am about this game but you may not be able to contribute financially. That's okay! Be sure to spread the word via social media and share this campaign with all you know; especially with those you know will contribute to this worthy project. Consider becoming an affiliate marketer, and earn money while you spread the word.
story_txt:
Short Summary

The United States has
a maternity care crisis; a rising maternal death rate, a national cesarean
section rate hovering at 33%, and an infant mortality
rate more than double that of Sweden, Japan, Portugal, Finland,
Norway, and the Czech Republic. At the same time, there has been a tremendous
decline in attendance at childbirth classes and an abundance of birth information
online. This has led to many women receiving inaccurate information at best.
 
When playing Down the Canal, learners are engaged in what they are discovering while having fun. This encourages not only retention of information, but an excitement and desire to want to know more.
This game will revolutionize the childbirth education experience. Childbirth educators can use it as part of their class series, doulas can share it with clients, and teachers can use it in the classroom. It allows for a personal and individual childbirth education when access to classes is a hardship. The game has 240 questions about pregnancy, birth, breastfeeding and more. 
By contributing to
this fundraising campaign, you will be assisting in the spread of accurate
information about birth, breastfeeding, birthing options and the newborn. Spreading
this information is how we can truly have an impact on the demand for normal
birth. 



During the testing phase, I received positive feedback from many birth professionals including doulas and childbirth educators, and from expectant parents.  From one childbirth educator: "While having fun, the game engages couples in a relaxed atmosphere." From one expectant parent: "Questions were great, brought a lot of good conversation. It's good to learn and review."
At the LamazeICEA conference Down the Canal was well received.  Attendees loved the colorful, inviting game board.  During one activity attendees use the conception and pregnancy cards to invoke discussion!!  There is a demand for Spanish translation. Many childbirth educators see the value in play, even for adults. The woman who won a FREE game at the raffle said, "Of all the things to win, I was hoping to win the game. I'm really excited."
Check out our website DowntheCanal.com and like our Facebook page.


About Me

It has always been important to me to educate expectant families, and young men
and women about the birth process. It is a normal physiological event that has
become feared rather than revered.  My desire is for people to play this game
and become hungry for more knowledge about birth and beyond. 
I am a visionary and
an activist. I’ve been a postpartum doula, and an advocate for normal birth,
since 1991. During my career I have trained hundreds of doulas and have served hundreds of
families. It is my passion and my calling.


I am on the leadership
team of Citrus County Birth and Beyond Professional Network and I serve on the
Board of the Florida Breastfeeding Coalition. I am a founding member of the Coalition
for Improving Maternity Services (CIMS) and served on its leadership team for two
years.
   What We Need & What You Get

I am raising funds to
manufacture this game in the United States. My goal is to produce 1,500 games, at
a cost of $25,000. This includes full production of the board, box, seven card
sets, game pieces, dice, and directions along with game packaging and
shipping.
I received quotes from
several companies, and found one that is a good fit. The four prototypes I had made are being shared with educators and doula trainers who are excited about the game and all its uses. 
I have a launch plan
in place and intend to initially target birth professionals. After my
successful launch in this market, I will then pursue classrooms, websites geared toward pregnant Moms, and retail. I
plan to sell the game at birth and health conferences as well as educational
trade shows. I will also leverage social media by networking online as well as
creating a presence through blogging. I have met and networked with hundreds of
birth professionals during my 20 year career. I can leverage these relationships
to build an affiliate program which will quickly increase sales of the game.  I also plan to sell to clinical providers for
use in their waiting room. Additionally, I see this game in some of the major
childbirth organizations' online stores and in catalogs that feature childbirth
education tools.

attendance at the Game

rate in 2013!!

broken? 2) How many of these surgeries are medically necessary? 3)What trends

story:
Mission

What is the project goal?

To develop a peer-based youth aviation community focused on RC aircraft design, build, and skill challenges to strengthen problem solving and increase exposure to technology.

Why is this important?

Society will be facing problems in the future that will require use of innovative technology, and aviation is expected to play a key role. Currently, few opportunities exist for youth challenges related to aviation technology. Problem solving, innovation, self-motivation, and personal responsibility are all key to success today. The labor force needs more people who know how to do things and are not afraid to build things with their hands; the ones who do not sit and wait for someone to tell them step-by-step how to do a task, but instead figure it out for themselves. This project will help cultivate these people and grow their understanding of aviation and the aeronautical sciences.

So how is your project going to help the community meet this challenge?

This will be accomplished by establishing a youth aircraft building community group to effectively introduce students to associated aviation technology, and help them gain exposure to both full scale and remote control operations (RC aircraft, multirotors, and entry level First-Person View (FPV)/Unmanned Aircraft Systems (UASs)). Students in successful education programs learn how to solve problems and have the opportunity to use technology solutions to do so, which is exactly what will be done here.

How will it be done?

This will be done through the design and build of low cost RC aircraft, hands-on setup and trial of entry level autonomous FPV systems and the related programming, expanding youth connections with local aviation resources in Upstate South Carolina (Experimental Aircraft Association (EAA)/Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association (AOPA)/Academy of Model Aeronautics (AMA)/Western Carolina RC (WCRC)/Triple Tree Aerodrome), promotion of attendance at local flying events, RC piloting skills training, and the development of participation events (streamer cutting combat, obstacle course challenges, autonomous competitions, etc.). Challenges will be set up for students to tackle, including having to design, build, test, refine, and then compete with their own design. Education will be more hands-on and project-based, integrating traditional liberal arts thinking into problem solving exercises that emphasize technology.

How This Project Is Different

This project is different in that it will be peer-to-peer and community-based (as opposed to school-based), and will allow all students to be independently involved, but still work together and collaborate in a community. Other programs, such as school robotics, offer similar structure, but unfortunately are limited in the number of participants that can be directly involved (primarily due to inherent costs of such programs). This project, because of its extremely low cost, allows all students involved to directly participate.

Why We Need Your Support

In order to get things off the ground with the Upstate SC Youth Aviators Club, we need build and challenge supplies. The airplanes flown will be based off of the free plans available from Flite Test (http://www.flitetest.com/), an organization dedicated to expanding the hobby through extremely inexpensive RC airplanes made out of "Dollar Tree" Foam Core, as well as designs that students come up with themselves. This allows complete airplanes to be very inexpensive (<$60), making it cost effective to teach piloting skills. The motor and Electronic Speed Control (ESC) are also part of a removable pod that can be transferred from plane to plane, so many different airplanes can be flown with one motor and ESC, further reducing cost. The platform of "Dollar Tree" Foam Core is perfect for designing and testing as well. Using free, open source CAD software, students will be able to design their own planes in 3D and then export the plans to be cut out, built, tested, refined, and then used to compete with against other students. Multirotor and low cost FPV equipment (~$300 for a complete setup including both) is also needed to introduce students to Unmanned Aircraft System (UAS) technology, which is expected to play a key role in the future. Especially with the autonomous capabilities of many flight control systems available today, students will be able to not only focus on the technology itself, but also how to apply that technology to solve real-world problems. Using low cost technology now available to RC hobby enthusiasts, the equipment we will be using is perfect for entry level exposure and can be scaled up based on need, growth, and support. Challenge supplies will also need to be purchased to set up and host events where students can come and compete. Giving students the opportunity to directly participate in technology-based activities where equipment can be shared in a collaborative manner is a great way to accomplish the goal of optimizing the resources available, making it possible to expose many students to the technology at a very low cost. All contributors who donate more than $50 will receive a handwritten, personalized Thank You note, and all sponsors who donate more than $1,000 will have the option to have their name or company logo put on all aircraft as well as identification as a sponsor wherever else suitable.

Project Levels

Primary Level

The initial goal of the project is to get a group of students not already involved with aviation building and flying RC airplanes and multirotors. Challenges will also be set up for students to compete in. This will establish a community for collaboration and peer mentoring, and prove the feasibility of the model.

Secondary Level

In the secondary level of the project, design will be incorporated. Students will design, build, test, refine, and then compete with their own aircraft in challenges. This level also includes very low cost FPV equipment, allowing students to fly using goggles as if they were in the cockpit of the aircraft. This opens up more opportunities for learning and challenge. Real-world application of technology will also be explored, such as using small Unmanned Aircraft Systems (sUASs) for conservation purposes. The group will also explore full scale aviation as well through resources available at Triple Tree Aerodrome, EAA Chapter #249, and other local aviation associations.

Stretch Goal Towards Vision

Once a solid community group has been established, proving the feasibility of the project and acting as a model for other groups to follow, efforts will transition to promoting school clubs that can be incorporated into high schools across the nation. By encouraging other schools and organizations to get involved, aviation and the benefits it brings can be expanded to a much larger audience, further benefiting the community.

If We Meet and Exceed Our Funding Goal

If we meet our goal, this project will have enough funds to enter the secondary level. Additional funds will be used to continue progress to higher levels, and will also allow the project to be done at a larger scale with more students being able to directly participate (more funds = more airplanes and multirotors = more pilots = larger program).

Vision

We envision having high schools across the United States and around the world involved with aviation challenges. In conjunction with school robotics programs, we see students designing, building, testing, refining, and programming small Unmanned Aircraft Systems (sUASs) used to compete in autonomous challenges similar to robotics, but in three dimensions. This would be more difficult, increasing the benefit of the program. It also exposes students to the technology available, and skills acquired will directly transfer to careers such as UAS operation.

About the Project Coordinator

"Adam is a junior at Greenville High School interested in advancing academic standards through student and community participation in STEM. He has been involved with Citizen Science initiatives for the past 5 years through participation in national programs such as FrogWatch USA, Secchi-Dip-In, World Water Monitoring Day, Adopt-A-Stream, 4-H, and has won associated awards. One of these projects involved establishment of a Citizen Science Club that received statewide recognition through SCDHEC’s “Champions of The Environment” grant award and the Environmental Education Association of South Carolina’s Student of the Year award for integration of a cross-state water monitoring program (Georgia Adopt-A-Stream) into a South Carolina school. His success with life sciences has been matched with technical participation in scholastic FIRST robotics and currently VEX robotics, including invitation to compete internationally at the 2015 VEX World Championship in Louisville, KY. Through his interest in aviation (cultivated by involvement with the Greenville EAA chapter for the past 5 years, and more recently with the local WCRC AMA club), he has identified new collaboration opportunities that can increase participation and exposure of youth to growing technologies. Please help him bring this concept into fruition."
